article.body: Microsoft plans to purchase game developer Bethesda Softworks' parent company in a $7.5 billion deal Microsoft Microsoft Corp. made a big bet on gaming Monday when it announced that it intends to purchase ZeniMax Media, the parent of game publisher Bethesda Softworks, for $7.5 billion in cash. The company wasted little time beefing up its consumer business after falling short in its attempt to buy the U.S. business of TikTok. With the ZeniMax Media acquisition, it sees room to enhance its Game Pass streaming service by adding Bethesdaâs franchises, including âThe Elder Scrollsâ and âFallout.â Microsoftâs stock MSFT, +2.48% was down 0.6% in midday trading Monday. He said that the deal makes sense strategically heading into Microsoftâs âhighly anticipated new console releaseâ and that it highlights how Microsoft ârecognizes its need for consumer-based revenue growth,â which this acquisition could help drive. Microsoft Chief Executive Satya Nadella said in a release that âquality differentiated content is the engine behind the growth and value of Xbox Game Pass,â while heralding gaming as âthe most expansive category in the entertainment industry.â The company intends to bring existing Bethesda titles to Game Pass and add future games to the service on the same day that they launch for Xbox and PC. Microsoft anticipates that the ZeniMax Media deal will close in the second half of fiscal 2021 and that it will have âminimal impactâ on the companyâs operating income for fiscal 2021 and fiscal 2022. Materne argued that gaming could become the âthird pillarâ of Microsoftâs investment narrative in the coming years as gaming-as-a-service becomes a more prominent part of the industry. In that world, âvendors that can provide gamers with a unique experience through the combination of having great content and a great platform are best positioned to take share in the $109 billion gaming market,â he wrote, while maintaining an outperform rating and $250 price target on Microsoftâs stock.
